Operations Center.From: Patty Lang
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Docket number 24-198: Reject the BlackRock takeover of Minnesota Power
Date: Wednesday, September 24, 2025 8:50:00 AM
Minnesota Public Utility Commission Docket ID No. 24-198,
Utilities are essential public services, not Wall Street moneymakers.When private equity firms took over Superior Water, Light and Power in Wisconsin, customers
saw double-digit rate increases every two years. In the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, a privateequity firm bought the Upper Peninsula Power Company, and customers have seen similarlylarge rate increases.
Approving the BlackRock takeover of Minnesota Power would open the floodgates for more
private equity firms to target utilities nationwide.
I urge you to reject this deal.Thank you,Patty Lang 
plang61@yahoo.com 5720 Stevens ave s Minneapolis, Minnesota 55419

Name * Lauren Parks
Provide the docket's number. Docket 24-198
Leave a comment on the docket. *
I am writing as a concerned citizen and ratepayer to express my strong opposition to the proposed
acquisition of Allete (parent company of Minnesota Power) by Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), aBlackRock-owned entity. This acquisition poses serious risks to consumers, transparency,Indigenous rights, and the states clean energy future.
1. Risk of Rate Hikes and Financial BurdenBlackRock and GIP are profit-driven private equity entities with a history of prioritizing short-term
financial returns. The premium paid for this acquisition is substantial  and without adequatesafeguards, that cost is likely to be passed on to ratepayers through higher utility bills. Minnesotansshould not be forced to subsidize Wall Street investment returns.
2. Greenwashing and Environmental DoublespeakBlackRock has been credibly accused of greenwashing, making misleading sustainability claims while
remaining one of the largest global investors in fossil fuels. Despite its public ESG posture, the firmcontinues to fund companies tied to deforestation, climate change, and environmental degradation.There is no assurance that BlackRock will honor any clean energy commitments made during thisprocess  especially as prior promises across its portfolio have often been vague andunenforceable.
3. Harms to Indigenous Communities and LandBlackRocks portfolio includes investments in companies that have been accused of violating
Indigenous land rights, displacing communities, and ignoring sovereign consent. Minnesotas publicutility infrastructure must not be placed under ownership that has a track record of environmentalinjustice.
4. Reduced Oversight and Public TransparencyUnlike public companies, private equity-owned utilities are less transparent. Critical decisions 
from infrastructure investment to pricing  could be made behind closed doors. That weakenspublic accountability and threatens the Commissions ability to oversee ratepayer protections.
5. Regulatory and Legal Concerns
BlackRock has faced multiple investigations and lawsuits related to anticompetitive behavior and ESG
misrepresentation. Notably:
The SEC charged BlackRock Advisors with misleading investors in 2023.A 2024 lawsuit in France alleged greenwashing on a global scale.In 2025, the State of Mississippi issued a cease and desist order related to energy collusion.
This pattern raises valid concerns about BlackRocks fitness to own and operate a regulated publicutility in Minnesota.
ConclusionApproving this deal would set a dangerous precedent  putting Wall Street profit motives ahead of
Minnesota families, small businesses, and environmental justice. The risks are too great, thebenefits too vague, and the track record of the buyer too troubling.
I respectfully urge the Commission to follow the recommendation of Administrative Law Judge
Megan J. McKenzie and reject the proposed sale of Allete to GIP / BlackRock.
Thank you for your attention to this critical matter.

Dear Members of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing in reference to PUC Docket No. 24-198 to state my opposition to the proposed
takeover of Minnesota Power by BlackRock.Minnesota Power plays a critical role in serving the energy needs of our communities,
supporting regional industries, and maintaining reliability across northern Minnesota. Controlof this vital utility should remain accountable to the people of our statenot to a globalinvestment firm whose primary obligation is to its shareholders.
A takeover of this nature raises serious concerns:
Local accountability and oversight:  Decisions affecting Minnesotas energy future
must remain under the guidance of a utility rooted in and responsive to the communities
it serves.
Long-term stability: Private equity or investment firms often focus on short-termreturns, which can come at the expense of necessary long-term infrastructureinvestments and ratepayer protections.
Energy independence and affordability: Minnesotans cannot risk higher rates,reduced service reliability, or a diminished focus on renewable energy development as aresult of profit-driven priorities.
For these reasons, I urge the Commission to reject this proposed acquisition. Minnesota Powershould remain under ownership and direction that prioritize the interests of its customers,employees, and the future energy needs of Minnesota.
Thank you for your consideration.Respectfully,
Todd Murchison1105 S 3rd Ave E Ely, MN 55731651.304.0345

As a now retired utility worker whose company narrowly averted being acquired by a private company, I can tell
you from experience that the purchasing company (in this case Blackrock) will say anything and agree to anythingto close the deal.  But once that is done those promises will go away and the rules will be lobbied away.  We werepromised many things but after the failed attempt and reporters getting access to internal emails through FOIArequests the plan the entire time was to enrich a few people in the C-suite and lay off about half the workforce. Ihave no doubt in my mind that Blackrock is probably using a similar playbook.  Utilities are a monopoly bygeography and as such should never be privatized. Giving up control of electricity or water infrastructure to aprivate company will always come back to haunt you. Just looking at Texas and the problems they have shouldshow you that private industry should not control utilities.

Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed sale of
Minnesota Power to institutional investors ultimately owned by BlackRock.
As a Minnesota Energy Justice Advocate, I believe that access to energy is
a fundamental human right, not a commercial opportunity. With thisacquisition, BlackRock would acquire 10 out of 13 board member seats,thereby gaining significantly more control over key decisions that would
affect one of Minnesotas essential utilities (Edstrom, 2025). This raises
serious concerns about rate increases and the prioritization of profit overpublic interest. Handing further control to the worlds largest asset managerswill force Minnesotans to fund the expansion of a trillion-dollar corporationthrough their utility bills. 
In Minnesota, our winters are not just cold, they are life-threatening. No
Minnesotan should ever have to choose between staying warm and stayingfinancially stable. Energy is necessary for survival and should be treated asso. I urge you to oppose this sale and prioritize the long-term interests of
Minnesotans over corporate profits.  
Sincerely,Chloe OlsonMinnesota Energy Justice Advocate 
Citations
Edstrom, B. (July 15, 2025). Judge recommends rejection of the private sale
of Minnesota Power.  Citizens Utility Board. https://cubminnesota.org/judge-
recommends-rejection-private-sale-minnesota-power

When I moved to Northern Minnesota in 2024, I was proud to build a home here. To join a
state that values its people, communities, and natural resources during my young adult life leftlike a dream. But, with the proposed AlleteBlackRock merger, that pride has started to fade.

I did not choose to build my life here only to see our future energy decisions handed off to

Minnesotans deserve a utility system that puts people, affordability, and clean energy first.

values profits and quotas before their citizens, which is heartbreaking to hear as a previouslyproud Duluthian.
I respectfully ask the Commission to say no to this merger and protect the long-term interests
of Minnesota residents.
Sincerely,Jonah Provance, a young Duluth Citizen.

To whom it may concern,
As a resident of northern Minnesota, I urge you  to reject the acquisition of Minnesota Power by
BlackRock. We simply cant afford to have another essential part of our lives sold off to private
equity. 
In their quest for excessive profits, private equity interests are hurting the most important parts of
our lives: Private equity makes finding an affordable place to live even harder for working people.
Private equity erodes our health and care system, closing hospitals and care facilities and
undermining quality. Private equity puts the cost of educating our kids that much farther out of
reach for those already struggling. 
And now private equity is coming for our utilities, the services that provide our electricity, heat, and
water that we need to survive. 
We know that private equity hurts public life by consolidating financial wealth and political power
into the hands of the few, skewing the one voice, one vote promise of a democratic governance.
At a time when corporate greed has a stronghold on the outcomes of elections and public decision
making across our country, Minnesotas leaders must push back and reclaim a governance for the
people, by the people. Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) Megan J. McKenzie issued a report including findings of fact and
conclusions of law with a recommendation that the Commission deny the proposed buyout. The
ALJ found that the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, Inc., parent company of Minnesota Power, by
Global Infrastructure Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board is not only
inconsistent with the public interest but that, if approved, the deal would result in net harm. 
The record shows that this proposed private equity buyout would only do harm to Minnesotans. I
urge you to protect the people and set an example for the rest of the country by denying this
proposal.
Sincerely,
Kristen Wesloh
9943 E. Lind Rd.
Angora, MN 55703kristen.wesloh@yahoo.com

content:
Elizabeth M. Brama 
612.977.8624 EBrama@taftlaw.com 
Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP / Taftlaw.com  2200IDSCenter,80South8thStreet
Minneapolis, MN554022210
Tel:612.977.8400 
taftlaw.com 
Affirmative Action,EqualOpportunity Employer  
September 24, 2025 
 
VIA ELECTRONIC FILING 
Sasha Bergman 
Executive Secretary Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 121 7th Place East, Suite 350 St. Paul, MN 55101-2147 
RE: In the Matter of the Peti tion of Minnesota Power for Ac quisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Invest ment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
Updated Stipulation: Conditions of  Acquisition and Preferred Decision 
Options MPUC Docket Nos. E015/PA-24-198  
Dear Ms. Bergman: 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power (Minnesota Power or the Company) 
submits this filing pursuant to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commissions 
(Commissions) September 11, 2025 Notice of Oral Argument Times and Procedures 
(Order). Specifically, the Commission direct ed that Parties are encouraged to meet and 
confer in efforts to work toward agreem ent on preferred decision options. Minnesota 
Power shall make a filing by September 24 su mmarizing the results of these efforts, and 
all parties should be prepared to discuss at  the September 25 Commission meeting. 
Consistent with this direction, Minnesot a Power, along with the Partners, reached 
out to all parties to this proceeding, as well as other interested parties, to assess potential 
agreement on Decision Options, including t he additional Decision Options proposed by 
Commissioners on September 16, 2025. We are very pleased to  share that the Company 
and Partners have agreed to a set of commitments t hat includes the large majority of the 
Commissioners additional Decision Opti ons. These agreements provide expansive 
additional benefits to customer s and the public interest above and beyond what is already 
provided in the Settlement. 
  
Docusign Envelope ID: F2DCA372-1B8D-4F45-B79C-EDF960A715DD
Ms. Bergman 
September 24, 2025 Page 2  
2 As directed by the Commission, we hav e worked with parties and stakeholders to 
reach agreement on preferred de cision options. To that end, Attachment A  to this filing 
reflects agreement by the following parti es and stakeholders on proposed Decision 
Options and overall resolution of this proceeding: 
 Minnesota Power; 
 The Minnesota Department of Commerce (Department); 
 Global Infrastructure Partners;  
 Canada Pension Plan In vestment Board;  
 Energy CENTS Coalition; 
 International Brotherhood of El ectrical Workers Local 31; 
 IUOE Local 49 and NCSRCC; 
 LiUNA Minnesota and North Dakota;  
 Fresh Energy;  
 Clean Grid Alliance;  
 Center for Energy and Environment; and  
 Clean Energy Economy Minnesota. 
 
Through the commitments in the Settl ement and the additional commitments 
outlined in Attachment A , the Partners have agreed to provide more than $100 million in 
rate credits and investor-funded investments for customers, in addition to a one-year rate 
case stay-out. 
Attachment B  to this filing identifies how agr eed Decision Options in Attachment 
A differ from proposed Commissioner Decision Options and provides explanations for modifications where we believe such explan ation may be helpful to the Commission. The 
Company, Partners, and Department  confirm that to the extent  their agreement in this 
filing to a Decision Option would constitute a modification of the Settlement Agreement 
between them, they would accept the modifi cations included in this letter without 
otherwise withdrawing fr om the Settlement. 
Minnesota Power, along with GIP and CPP Inve stments, also reached out to each 
of the Office of the Attorney General-Residential Utilit ies Division, Citiz ens Utility Board 
(MN), CURE, Sierra Club, and Large Power Inte rvenors to determine whether they would 
support approval of the Acquisition or ot herwise modify their positions should the 
Commission adopt any combination of the new Commissioner Decision Options.  These 
parties each stated that they would not support the Acquisiti on, and that the Commissions 
new Decision Options would not affect their opposition to the Acquisition.  
  
Docusign Envelope ID: F2DCA372-1B8D-4F45-B79C-EDF960A715DD
Ms. Bergman 
September 24, 2025 Page 3  
3 We appreciate the careful attention and dedica tion of time to this important matter 
by the Commission and Commission Staff. Pleas e feel free to contact the undersigned 
with any questions.  
 
Sincerely, 
 
Elizabeth M. Brama 
Kodi J. Verhalen Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP (612) 977-8400 ebrama@taftlaw.com  
kverhalen@taftlaw.com  
 
Counsel for ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power  
cc: Service List 
Docusign Envelope ID: F2DCA372-1B8D-4F45-B79C-EDF960A715DD
Attachment A  
Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
 
1 ADDENDUM TO SETTLEMENT STIPULATION  
 
This Addendum to Settlement Stip ulation, which shall be effective as  of the date of the signatures 
below, is entered into for purposes of jointly recommending that the matter before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Co mmission) in Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 is consistent with 
the public interest in compliance with Minn. Stat .  216B.50 in light of the commitments in the 
Settlement Stipulation and in this Addendum. 
 WHEREAS , on July 11, 2025, the Minne sota Department of Co mmerce, ALLETE Inc. d/b/a 
Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investme nt Board, and Global Infrastructure Partners 
(each a Settling Party and collectively the Settling Parties) entered into a Settlement 
Stipulation (the Settlement)
1 through which they developed a series of commitments responsive 
to concerns raised by the Department and as a result of which each Settling Party supports 
Commission approval of the proposed Acquisition as consistent with th e public interest;  
 WHEREAS , in light of the proposed Decision Options filed on September 16, 2025 by 
Commissioners, Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, and Global Infrastructure Partners have agreed to additi onal conditions as described in this Addendum;   
 WHEREAS , since the date of the Settlement, additi onal entities wish to expressly join the 
Settlement and Addendum in suppor t of it and all its terms;  
 WHEREAS , the following parties to  this Acquisition proceeding join this Addendum to 
Settlement: the Internat ional Brotherhood of El ectrical Workers Local 31, LIUNA Minnesota and 
North Dakota, North Central Stat es Regional Council of Carpenters and the International Union 
of Operating Engineers Local 49, and Energy CE NTS Coalition (collect ively the Additional 
Parties); and  WHEREAS , the following non-parties also wish to join this Addendum to Settlement: Fresh 
Energy; the Clean Grid Alliance; the Center for Energy and Environment; and Clean Energy 
Economy Minnesota (collectively the Additional Signatories) (the Settling Parties, the 
Additional Parties, and the Additional Signato ries, together, the Resolving Parties). 
 NOW, THEREFORE , in consideration of the promises an d mutual agreement contained in this 
Addendum to Settlement Stipulation, the Resolving Parties agree as follows:  
 
1. The Resolving Parties have reviewed the Se ttlement signed by the Department, Minnesota 
Power, GIP, and CPP Investments filed on July 11, 2025.   
2. The Resolving Parties have reviewed all D ecision Options filed by the Minnesota Public 
Utilities Commission Staff on September 11, 2025, and the additional Decision Options 
filed by the Commissioners on September 16, 2025.  
 
1 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment 
Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , Docket No. E015/PA-24-198, Settlement Stipulation (July 11, 2025) 
(eDocket No. 20257-220879-01 ). All defined terms and acronyms included  in this Addendum shall have the same 
meaning as set forth in the Settlement, unless otherwise defined herein. 
Docusign Envelope ID: F2DCA372-1B8D-4F45-B79C-EDF960A715DD
Attachment A  
Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
 
2  
3. The Resolving Parties hereby incorporate the Settlement, including al l of its terms and 
provisions, in full, except to the extent that a ny of the terms or provisi ons of the Settlement 
are modified in this Addendum to Settlement Stipulation. Fo r the avoidance of doubt, this 
includes the General Provisions in Para graphs 2.2 through 2.9 of the Settlement. 
 
4. The Resolving Parties support adoption of th e Decision Options here in, including those 
that add to or modify the Settlement.  
5. The Resolving Parties conclude  that the terms of this Addendum further enhance the 
benefits of the Acquisition and further redu ce any risks to Minnesota Power customers, 
stakeholders, and the public as set forth in the Settlement, and further underscore that the 
Acquisition is in the public interest.  
6. The Resolving Parties jointly recommend that the Commission approve the Acquisition 
including all terms, conditions, and commit ments included in the Settlement and 
Addendum.  
7. Minnesota Power, GIP, CPP Investments, and the Department confirm that to the extent 
their agreement in this filing to a Decision Op tion constitutes a modification of the July 11, 
2025 Settlement, they accept the modifications included in th is letter without otherwise 
withdrawing from the Settlement.  
8. The Resolving Parties support adoption of the following Decision Options: 
a. The Resolving Parties to the Addendum to Settlement Sti pulation recommend 
adoption of Staff Decision Options 5, 7A a nd B, 8 as modified below, 10, 11, 13A 
as modified below, 15, 16A-F, 17A-C, 18, 19A-K,
2 20, and 21.3 
b. 8. Staff:  Require Minnesota Power to file in this docket an  annual report 
documenting any adjustments to the 5-year capital investment plan, with an 
explanation of why the adjust ments are reasonable, prudent , and consistent with the 
goals of Settlement Stipul ation Paragraphs 1.31.4 to en sure the availability of 
investment funds and the enforceability of  the capital commitment. Further require 
that Minnesota Power make an interim report, providing the same information, if 
there are any adjustments to  the 5-year capital invest ment plan between annual 
reports. 
c. 13A. Staff:  Direct the Executive Secretary to modify the ALJ report as specified 
herein and to otherwise modi fy, reject, or add any findings  or conclusions, including 
incorporating modifications  proposed by Minnesota Power, the Partners, the

Ham New 23 . Minnesota Powers rate of return  on equity is capped at 7.25309.78 percent (as 
approved in Docket No. E-015/GR-23-155) and Minnesota Powers equity ratio in its capital 
structure will be capped at 53.0 percent until December 31st, 2030. This  condition does not prohibit 
Minnesota Power from filing new rate cases  or from proposing in rate cases what an ROE would 
be absent the temporary cap . The Commission may reduce the rate of return on equity by up to 
100 basis points if it finds any significant viol ation of conditions imposed in this docket.  
Explanation of Proposed Changes: Custome rs are already protected by Settlement 
Paragraph 1.12 from potential increases in the cost of debt as a result of the 
Acquisition. It is reasonable for the Company  to have the opportunity to demonstrate 
that any increases in the cost of debt are caused by forces outside of its control, such 
as interest rates and tariffs. The Company and Partners agree, however, to a cap to 
Minnesota Powers last-authorized ROE,  which does not change the Settlement 
establishing a lower ROE of 9.65 percent until the Companys next rate case. Petitioners also agree to a fix ed equity ratio to  further address c oncerns about over-
leveraging the Company. The additional proposed modifications seek to reflect that (1) 
the Company and Partners are not agreeing that market conditions will dictate any 
particular ROE for the next five years; and (2) violation of conditions could be 
penalized in the form of reductions to inves tor returns, apart from the cost of debt.

Powers response to IR 12) unless approved by the Commission  in a general rate case .

whenever possible and shall require contractors a nd subcontractors to pay their workers prevailing 
wage.

transaction. and all existing collective bargai ning agreements will be honored.  This 
provision shall be subject to vo luntary departures and termina tions in the ordinary course 
and shall not apply to any nonunion employee who voluntarily agrees to a change in position 
or location. The Company acknowledges IBEW Local 31s exclusive representation as 
identified in current collectiv e bargain agreements and will continue to honor agreements 
as they are bargained.

The Partners and Minnesota Power acknowle dge Minnesota Powers obligations under 
Minnesotas Carbon Free Standard Law and commit to support Mi nnesota Power with 
additional expertise and capital as necessary to enable Minnesota Power to comply with the 
Carbon Free Standard through implementation of Commission Orders, including in IRP and 
related dockets. commit to effo rts to achieve Minnesotas Ca rbon Free Standard with least

7 cost pathways to compliance ultimately de termined by the Commission in IRP and related 
dockets.   
 
Partridge New 38 (unchanged) . Minnesota Power shall work with  the Minnesota Department of 
Commerce and other participants in Docket No. E015/RP-25-127 to develop an alternative resource 
plan scenario without the 750 MW of new comb ined-cycle natural gas resources proposed in 
Minnesota Powers March 3, 2025 integrated resource plan. By December 15, 2025, Minnesota 
Power shall file the alternative scenario accompanied by a qualitative description of the scenario and its costs and benefits, as well as a quantita tive analysis of how the scenario performs on the 
factors listed in Minnesota Rules part 7843.0500, subpart 3. 
 
Tuma New 39A . Within 30 days after the order, the Company shall make a compliance filing 
identifying the fulltime equivalent employee (FTE)  count and the number of employees in each 
category or division of Minnesota Power such as call center staff, billing, distribution system 
maintenance, power plant mainte nance etc transmission and distri bution, generation, and operations 
support services. The reporting shall identify how many FTEs are union versus nonunion and their 
work locations. The reporting shall id entify contractor work hours re lated to the job classifications 
covered under the Companys current collective bargaining agreement. The Commission delegates 
authority to the Executive Secretary to approve  the division classification made by Minnesota 
Power if no objection is filed by the Department or OAG within 14 days of the compliance filing. 
Additionally, Minnesota Power shall list the number of those employees with  their primary work 
location in Minnesota and the number of FTEs pr esently unfilled at the time of the filing.  
 
Tuma New 39B . The Company shall make compliance filings quarterly, on dates designated by 
the Executive Secretary or by the Commission  in a rate case order , reporting the number of FTEs, 
unfilled FTEs, employees and their primary work lo cation for the divisions on the metrics identified 
in 39A identified in the initial filing or modifica tions approved by the Commission.  
 
Tuma New 39C . So long as Minnesota Power is owned by Alloy Parent or any successor company 
affiliated with Global Infrastructure Partners or Canada Pension Plan  Investment Board, the 
Company may not reduce the identified FTE complement for any of these divisions each business 
area identified in Decision Option 39A by more th an 10 percent below Minnesota Powers 5-year 
historic average employment (as of the date of the Acquisition) or move the prim ary work location 
out of Minnesota outside of a rate case without prior Commission approval. The FTE count for each 
category and associated primary locations shal l be reset with approval of the Commission  in future 
rate case orders . 
Tuma New 39D . Upon filing a request to modify the FTE co unt in Minnesota or to relocate jobs 
to primary sites outside of Minnesota  (unless it relates to a Company asset located outside of 
Minnesota) between rate cases, the Company must show such actions are reas onable, prudent, will 
not reduce service quality, and are in the public interest. The Commis sion delegates authority to the 
Executive Secretary to approve the request if no objection is made by the Department or OAG and 
no request for further investigation is made by a Commissioner within 14 days of the filing of any such request.

Operations Center.From: Dustin Thomas
To: Staff, CAO (PUC) ; puc.docketing@state.mn.us
Subject: Letter of Opposition to BlackRocks Acquisition of Minnesota Power
Date: Friday, September 19, 2025 1:24:12 PM
You don't often get email from drthomas149@hotmail.com. Learn why this is important
September 19, 2025
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission
121 7th Place E., Suite 350Saint Paul, MN 55101
To the Honorable Commissioners:I write as a resident and consumer in central Minnesota to urge you to reject the
proposed acquisition of Minnesota Power by BlackRocks Global Infrastructure Partnersand the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. I believe this transaction will not servethe people of our state well and will instead saddle us with higher utility bills, underminethe reliability of our energy supply, and erode community trust in our essential services.
An Administrative Law Judge concluded unequivocally that the sale would result in net
harm to the public interest and poses an unacceptable risk of rate increase and rateshock in a critical and economically vulnerable area of Minnesota. [43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054]( https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/puc-must-unplug-
minnesota-power-122321434.html?citationMarker=43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-
981daa162054  "1")
Minnesota Power currently serves roughly 150,000 residential and business customersacross northeast and north central Minnesota. Under private equity ownership, thebuyers are planning significant rate increases, yet have offered no bindingcommitments to keep rates just and reasonable for families and small businessesalready facing economic pressures. [43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/puc-must-unplug-minnesota-power-
122321434.html?citationMarker=43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054  "1")
BlackRock and its partners are driven by the private equity modelpursuing 1520%
annual returns for investors. History shows that such firms often cut costs in ways thatcompromise service reliability, delay infrastructure upgrades, and transfer wealth fromratepayers to Wall Street shareholders. Minnesota Powers customers should notbecome a revenue stream for executives headquartered thousands of miles away.[43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/puc-must-unplug-minnesota-power-
122321434.html?citationMarker=43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054  "1")
Moreover, this deal threatens our communitys clean-energy goals. While the buyerstout expertise in renewable infrastructure, the administrative law judge found noevidence they would commit capital to Minnesota Powers transition to carbon-freeelectricity. Instead, information redacted as trade secret prevents public assessmentof their true intentions. [43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/puc-must-unplug-minnesota-power-
122321434.html?citationMarker=43dcd9a7-70db-4a1f-b0ae-981daa162054  "1")
For these reasons, I respectfully urge the Commission to protect Minnesotans interestsby denying approval of the BlackRock acquisition. Our region deserves a utility ownerwhose primary obligation is to its customers and its communitynot to distant investorsseeking short-term profits at our expense.
Thank you for your careful consideration.Sincerely,Dustin Thomas 
12745 Hillton RdLittle Falls MN 56345

I live and work in Duluth, MN with Mn Power/Allete as my energy provider.  I adamantly oppose the sale to private
equity firms CPP and GIP.  Energy is an essential service, and I do not want it in the hands of private equitymonopolies.

handled much better and with the betterment of the community in the hands of current ownership instead ofCPP/GIP/BlackRock.  Private Equity firms have a documented history in the Upper Peninsula of raising rates morethan publicly traded utilities and of then selling to yet another private equity firm who again raised rates. NorthernWI has a citizens grassroots campaign trying to buy their utility back from private equity due to the disastrousresults.
Communities are strongest when essential services are owned more broadly by many in the community.  MN Power
owns a lot of land, mineral rights, and even control over lakes and rivers that so many in our community live anddepend on.  I dont want that ownership to transfer to private equity.
Private Equity firms also have a history of just paying state level fines rather than following state mandates to
improve utilities for the good of the whole community. Promises made before a sale mean little when the motive ismoney, not communities.  Please stop this deal in its tracks.  Do NOT set a precedence of allowing private equity firms to purchase our
essential energy service companies.
Stay strong,Stephanie KieroSent from my iPhone

To the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am a landowner in Cook County and while I get my power from Arrowhead Cooperative, I still feel
this sale matters for people like me. Even if I am not their direct customer, Minnesota Power is tiedinto the same transmission grid and owns a lot of generation in northern Minnesota. The decisionsmade by new private equity owners will spill over into my community one way or another.
My biggest concern is the environment. Cook County and northern Minnesota are some of the last
places in the Midwest where you can still find real wilderness and clean water. My land is part of this.I rely on the forest and clean water here, and I worry that once private equity takes control, thoseprotections will be put second to financial returns. We are on the edge of Lake Superior, theBoundary Waters, and a forest that people come from all over the country to see. If profit becomesthe main driver, I fear decisions about dams, transmission corridors, or renewable projects will bemade without full accountability to the people who live here and depend on this land. That threatensnot just the beauty of the region but my own ability to use and enjoy my land.
Accountability is also a major issue. Right now, Minnesota Power answers to Minnesota regulators
and the public. If this sale goes through, decisions will be driven by investors far from here whohave no stake in our communities except the money they can make. In Ohio, we saw how utilityownership and private financial influence led to the HB6 corruption scandal, where public trust waslost and billions in costs were pushed onto ratepayers. In Indiana, private utility sales andrestructuring have led to higher bills and less local control, with profits leaving the state instead ofstaying in local communities. I dont want Minnesota to follow those same paths.
This sale will also send money out of Minnesota. Instead of reinvesting earnings back into our
communities, profits will be siphoned off to corporations and investors elsewhere. That means lessmoney circulating in Minnesota towns, fewer resources for local improvements, and less autonomyfor citizens. A short-term influx of cash does not outweigh the long-term loss of accountability,transparency, and economic benefit for Minnesota communities.
For these reasons, I urge the Commission not to approve this sale. Minnesota Power is critical
infrastructure. It should remain under oversight that prioritizes the public interest, not private equity
returns. Rejecting this sale is the only way to guarantee accountability, protect our environment, and
keep decision-making rooted in Minnesota.
Thank you for considering my perspective as a Cook County landowner.Best,
Jacob

Re: Docket No. E-015/PA-24-198  Proposed Acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments and Global
Infrastructure Partners
Dear Commissioners,I urge you to deny the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, parent company of Minnesota Power, by
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP, a BlackRockaffiliate). After reviewing the record, including the Administrative Law Judges Findings of Fact,Conclusions of Law, and Recommendations, I believe the deal is not in the public interest. The risksto ratepayers, transparency, and Minnesotas clean-energy goals outweigh the claimed benefits.
1. Risk to Ratepayers / Potential Rate Increases
The ALJ found that Petitioners are paying a premium of roughly $1.5 billion above ALLETEs bookvalue, and nearly 2022% above market value at the time of the announcement (ALJ Report  460465) . Such an overpayment must be recovered somehow, and history shows the costs ultimatelyflow to customers. While the settlement agreement offers temporary rate protections (e.g., a one-year freeze), the ALJ concluded these do not address the long-term risks associated with thepremium price (ALJ Report  472).
2. Loss of Transparency and Oversight
If ALLETE is taken private, it will no longer be required to make SEC filings such as quarterly andannual reports (Form 10-Q/10-K). This eliminates a key source of visibility into operations andfinancial health (ALJ Report  329333) . The record also documents extensive redactions andtrade secret claims that limited the ability of intervenors and the public to fully evaluate Petitionersplans (ALJ Report  335).
3. Questionable Clean-Energy Justification
Petitioners argue the acquisition is needed to provide capital for compliance with Minnesotas 2040Carbon-Free Standard. The ALJ disagreed, finding Petitioners failed to prove that the transactionmaterially improves access to capital (ALJ Report  523527) . Moreover, Minnesota Powers ownIntegrated Resource Plan continues to propose new natural-gas generation, undermining claims that
the acquisition advances carbon-free goals.
4. Private Equity Conflicts of Interest
Private equity firms target returns above those typical of regulated utilities, relying on financialengineering and cost-cutting that may conflict with the public interest. Expert testimony in therecord outlined these risks (ALJ Report  402410) . The experience of the Upper Peninsula PowerCompany in Michigan under private ownership  where rates rose significantly and transparencydeclined  illustrates what Minnesotans could face .
5. Settlement Agreement Fails to Mitigate Harms
The Department of Commerces settlement agreement contains some protections, but the ALJ notedthey are largely temporary or duplicative of existing obligations and do not fundamentally changethe risks associated with the transaction (ALJ Report  480) .
6. ALLETE Can Raise Capital Without the Acquisition
In testimony to regulators, Petitioners acknowledged ALLETE could access capital marketsindependently. The ALJ concluded the acquisition is not necessary for ALLETE to fund its resourceplan or meet Minnesotas clean-energy law (ALJ Report  526528) .
Conclusion
Minnesota law requires that utility ownership changes serve the public interest. Here, the recorddemonstrates the opposite: higher risks of rate increases, diminished transparency, andquestionable clean-energy benefits. For these reasons, I urge the Commission to deny theacquisition.
If the Commission nevertheless considers conditional approval, I request binding, enforceable
protections including:
Long-term (not temporary) ratepayer protections,Full transparency of financial, governance, and investment plans,Local oversight with enforceable authority,Limits on return on equity,Codified commitments consistent with the 2040 carbon-free standard, andGuarantees that infrastructure costs for private data centers are borne by the companies themselves,
not customers.
Minnesotans deserve utility ownership that puts affordability, accountability, and environmental
responsibility ahead of private equity profit. Please protect the public interest and deny thisacquisition.
Respectfully submitted,
Kristina Wodash

people, communities, and natural resources during my young adult life left like a dream. But, with the proposedAlleteBlackRock merger, that pride has started to fade.

residents.
Sincerely,
Emma Baker, a young Duluth Citizen.

Hello PUC,
I am writing as an extremely  concerned resident of Minnesota who spends a great deal of
time in and has a great deal of affection for the regions of the state covered by Minnesota
Power. That is why I am writing today to say that the sale of Minnesota Power to BlackRockmust under no circumstances be allowed to occur
. 
As was shown in the ruling of Judge Megan McKenzie, the sale  would result in net harm to
the public interest likely in the form of higher costs to consumers and less accountability. 
Judge McKenzie's report stated that the buyers had displayed a lack of cooperation during
the proceedings, which raises concerns about BlackRock's trustworthiness and highlights
the risk that they wont be transparent with the public if they are allowed to purchaseMinnesota Power.
BlackRocks $11.5 trillion in assets (larger than the GDP of every country on Earth excluding
the U.S. and China) make it the very definition of a company that i s too large to
regulate . What recourse would the state of Minnesota have against a company with that
amount of wealth and power if they were to start destroying one of the most naturally beautifulregions in the state? What recourse would everyday citizens have if their rates are suddenlyraised beyond what they are able to pay, in order to satiate private equitys endless greed? Theanswer is none. BlackRock has no stake in Minnesota, there is no way to hold them
accountable for their promises  and therefore no sale to them should be entertained. 
In addition to the lack of accountability, the alleged benefits of the sale are in no way
supported by the facts . 
1. Allete and BlackRock claim that consumers would not suffer excessive rate hikes as a result
of the sale, but judge McKenzie disagrees. Judge McKenzies report stated that BlackRock is
planning on significant rate increases  and that the sale  creates an unacceptable  risk of
rate increase  and rate shock in a critical and economically  vulnerable  area of Minnesota .
As one article so eloquently put it, Minnesotas energy future deserves better than
BlackRocks empty promises.
2. Allete cited BlackRocks expertise on utility infrastructure and renewable energy as areason why the sale would be beneficial. Judge McKenzie disagreed, stating that BlackRocksexpertise is unlikely to provide a material benefit to Minnesota Power or its ratepayers .
Allete already has quality management and near perfect reliability for its electric service.
3. Allete claims the sale will benefit Minnesota because the new partners were intentionally
and strategically chosen to achieve Minnesotas environmental goals. However, according toJudge McKenzie the evidence shows the Partners were ultimately the only bidders for the
company and were chosen based on their willingness to pay a stock premium. 
3.a. It should be noted that BlackRocks commitment to environmental goals isquestionable at best. As the Judge stated, The nonpublic evidence reveals the buyers
intent [is] to do what private equity is expected to do  pursue profit in excess ofpublic markets through company control. BlackRock's size and capital imbue themwith the power to essentially ignore Minnesota's environmental regulations. Any feesthey would accrue would be negligible to them, and what chance does the MinnesotaState Legislature have against a firm like BlackRock?
4. The Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (CUB), a  party to the contested case, has
questioned BlackRocks environmentally conscious image:  BlackRock just left a coalition
aimed at aligning the asset management industry with global climate goals, causing thecoalition to suspend its activities, it wrote. Further, BlackRock oversees an enormousamount of shares in fossil fuel companies and has a history of opposing climate-related
shareholder motions at these companies.
BlackRock is not seeking to buy Minnesota Power out of a sudden, vested interest in
providing safe, dependable services to our local communities. They are interested in thispurchase because they want to cash in on the soaring electricity demand from AI data centers.BlackRock is moving very aggressively to insert themselves at every level of the AI 'armsrace', from investing in data centers to software, and now even into the energy companies thatpower these data centers. They are not interested in Minnesota, they are only interested inprofit.
Electricity is an essential service needed by all members of our community, and its
management should not be handed off to an organization with a track record like
BlackRocks. 
For a look at what Minnesotans can expect if this sale is allowed to occur, we need look no
further than Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The power Company UPPCO was acquired byprivate equity in 2014 and has since seen 4 rate hikes since, and has been sold to yet anotherprivate equity firm. There is nothing stopping BlackRock from doing the same in Minnesota
.
If the PUC approves this sale in spite of the overwhelming  evidence against it , it would be
another painful example of how large industries have captured our states regulatory
system, making the agencys mission of improving the lives of all Minnesotans more of a
slogan, and less of a reality .
I encourage all members of the PUC to watch this video, as it sheds a great deal of light on thesituation and makes clear what a mistake it would be for the predatory BlackRock to beallowed to purchase Minnesota Power: The BlackRock Situation Just Got Worse
Additionally, this article
 is another valuable resource that makes plain the situation at hand.
Best,
Marina Norby

This message may be from an external email source.Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT ServicesSecurity Operations Center.
________________________________
Dear Commissioners,
This email is to urge the Commission to reject any sales or changes that would put Minnesotas public utilities under
private equity control or lead to privatization.
Utilities are not profit centers, they are essential services. If run for private gain, our communities face higher costs,
lower reliability, and less accountability. Dont Minnesotans deserve utilities that remain transparent, affordable,and publicly accountable?
Please act in our best interest and keep our utilities public, focusing on the long-term good of our communities.Sincerely,
Drew Bentrott.
[drew.bentrott@icloud.com].St Paul, MN.
